post.content:
Hmmm... I could not think of not using a credit card for on-line shopping.

There are a few forms in providing on-line transactions including your example
and still new ideas and technologies are being rolled out even though the concept
behind does not look to be much different from each other.

* Using a broker(?) membership

One of the earliest (mid-nineties) and primitive(?) style. Establish a third party
company that handles transactions for both seller and buyer. This company may be
doing credit card clearing by itself.

A buyer becomes a member (with norminal membership like $5.00 per year for example)
and gets assigned with an ID. This ID is used when purchasing products from the seller.
This company bills (usually through a credit card account) the buyer and the seller bills this company. The company gets some commision in return.

* Using a credit card clearing house

Again using a third party clearing house. This seems to be one of the most usual
(for small businesses) patterns these days. By the time when a buyer clicks the 'purchase'
button (after submitting his/her credit card info.), the clearing house performs necessary transactions on behalf of the seller. The money stays in the account of the clearing house
for a while before being transfered to the seller's account (after deducting a certain percentage
of the total transaction amount). For more information on this, search for web on something
like 'credit card clearing service'. Also see how to choose a clearing house at
http://www.workz.com/content/476.asp

* Seller membership

If your business is big enough so everybody knows, buyers might want to be a member
of your shopping service, so you know how to charge them since they need to provide the
membership ID for purchasing.

* Deposit using a financial institution (your example)

I think I have never seen this form other than when using a government agency service.
When you file your tax return using the Internet, you may owe some money to you-know-what
agency :-) You can deposit that amount through one of the several designated financial
institutions. Even in this case, you might want to make an on-line deposit.

Some new forms are still evolving like MS eMoney and we will see how it will fly (or die?).

There might be some other methods as well, so continue your research and enjoy!
